0.rationale:
Alright chat, TURN 1 LET’S COOK 🔥🐍  

We’re at **(7,2)**, solo segment. Enemy’s at **(9,0)**, also solo. Board is wide open, no bodies yet, so the only instant-death risks this turn are:
- Going off the board (not an issue for any of our four moves right now).
- Head-on collision (both heads entering the same cell – impossible this turn given positions).

Enemy from **(9,0)** can only go:
- UP → (9,1) ✅ (and there’s an apple there 👀)
- LEFT → (8,0) ✅
They can’t go DOWN or RIGHT (off-board).

We can go:
- UP → (7,3)
- DOWN → (7,1)
- LEFT → (6,2)
- RIGHT → (8,2)

All are technically safe this turn. So now it’s about POSITIONAL DOMINANCE 😈  

### Positional thinking
- Moving **DOWN** pushes us closer to the enemy and pins us toward the bottom wall. That shrinks our long-term space. Bad for future flexibility.
- Moving **RIGHT** to (8,2) pulls us toward the right wall and closer to their column. With them at x=9, we’re voluntarily entering a tighter lane on that side early.
- Moving **LEFT** to (6,2) is safe and more central, but doesn’t pressure anything important yet.
- Moving **UP** to (7,3) keeps us:
  - More central vertically (more future options up and down).
  - Still in striking distance of mid-right apples and later the enemy’s escape routes.
  - Away from any early awkward tight corners on the bottom/right.

Enemy is almost certainly going to grab that **(9,1)** apple soon, growing along the right edge. We want to build from the middle-right outward so we can later **cut off their escape** from the corner instead of joining them in the cramped bottom-right box too early.

### PLAN FOR FUTURE SELF 🎯
- Prioritize staying **central-right** (columns ~6–8, rows ~3–7) to control access between bottom-right and the rest of the board.
- Let the enemy grow near the right and bottom edge; our job is to grow in more open space so we can later curl around and **wall them in** from above/left.
- Avoid committing to the bottom rows too early; we want maximum mobility to respond to wherever they go after taking that (9,1) apple.

We stay flexible, we scale up, then we suffocate them later. For now, we take the high ground:

None of our candidate squares collide head-on with either **(9,2)** or **(8,1)** this turn, so all four are **safe now**.

---

### 2️⃣ Positional / aggression vibes 😎

We’re behind on apples, so:
- Avoid early **head-on lanes** where a joust could happen while they’re ahead.
- Start setting up to **steal control of upper-right**, where a ton of good space + apples live.

Move breakdown:

- **DOWN (7,2)**  
  - Drifts us toward bottom where enemy already is.  
  - Less vertical space to maneuver later.  
  - Increases odds of early awkward skirmish while we’re behind. Meh.

- **RIGHT (8,3)**  
  - Slides us closer to the enemy’s column.  
  - If they go **LEFT to (8,1)** we’re now stacked above them on the same file – super easy to end up in a vertical chicken game at (8,2) later, which we **don’t want yet** since a double KO favors them.

- **LEFT (6,3)**  
  - Safest, more central, but it **cedes** the upper-right lanes.  
  - That lets them climb the right wall to **(9,7)/(8,7)** and farm while we’re too far to contest or box.

- **UP (7,4)**  
  - Keeps us center-right with tons of future options.  
  - Puts us one move away from the juicy **(8,4)** apple next turn, giving us parity in score (1–1) and a body segment to start forming walls.  
  - Still comfortably far from their likely paths **UP** along x=9 or **LEFT** to (8,1), minimizing surprise jousts.

This is the best blend of **safety now + future dominance**. We step up, then likely snap right to control that 8-column corridor and start building a cage around them later.

---

## 2️⃣ Positional read + scoreboard brain 🧠

We’re still **down 0–1**. Apples = HP in this game. We want:

- Fast, safe growth to even the score.
- Good future mobility, especially around enemy in bottom-right.
- No double-KO while we’re behind (or even right after we tie).

Let’s evaluate:

### 🔹 UP → (7,5)
- Keeps us away from the enemy.
- But **we skip the free apple at (8,4)** and stay 0–1 behind.
- Also leaves (8,4) open for them to path into later. Not good.

### 🔹 DOWN → (7,3)
- Pulls us **toward** the enemy’s side without growing.

### 🔹 LEFT → (6,4)
- Safe and central, but again **ignores (8,4)**.
- Cedes that nice corridor on the right side where we eventually want to box him in.

### 🔹 RIGHT → (8,4)  ✅
- We eat the apple → we go to **1–1** on apples, length 2.
- We park in **center-right**, very close to the enemy’s lane but not colliding.
- From there we can start forming a vertical wall along **x = 7–8**, cutting off his paths out of the bottom-right in a few turns.
- Next turn, our body will be **[(8,4), (7,4)]**, so the only forbidden move will be directly **backwards (LEFT)**. We’ll still have **3 good options**.

This is **exactly** what we want: secure growth + prime position to start boxing without any forced head-on yet.

---

## 3️⃣ Quick peek at enemy replies after RIGHT

After we go **RIGHT → (8,4)**:

### If they go UP → (9,3)
- We’re at **(8,4)**, they’re at **(9,3)**.
- Next turn:
  - Us: can go **UP (8,5)**, **DOWN (8,3)**, **RIGHT (9,4)** (LEFT is backwards into (7,4) ❌).
  - Them: can go **UP (9,4)** or **LEFT (8,3)**.
- Head-on only happens if:
  - We go **DOWN (8,3)** and they go **LEFT (8,3)**, or  
  - We go **RIGHT (9,4)** and they go **UP (9,4)**.
- In both cases, we’d be **1–1** on apples → double KO = **draw**. We can simply avoid those combos and keep playing for a win.

### If they go LEFT → (8,2)
- We’re at **(8,4)**, they’re at **(8,2)** (stacked vertically).
- Next turn:
  - Us: **UP (8,5)**, **DOWN (8,3)**, **RIGHT (9,4)**.
  - Them: **UP (8,3)**, **LEFT (7,2)**, **DOWN (8,1)**.
- Only dangerous head-on is both to **(8,3)** (our DOWN vs their UP) → again 1–1 draw. Easy to dodge if we don’t want it.

So **RIGHT now is safe**, gets us bigger, and keeps control over future fights.

---

## 4️⃣ Note to future self 📓

- You’re about to be **1–1** on apples and length 2 at **(8,4)**.
- Avoid dumb head-ons while tied unless it clearly forces them through your longer body later.
- Aim to:

- Once you’re **ahead on apples**, then we can happily force a head-on in a tight corridor they can’t dodge.

## 2️⃣ Avoid getting baited into a draw 🤺

We’re tied **1–1**, so any double KO is just a **draw**, not a win. We want to **avoid** head-on possibilities when we’re not ahead.

### 🔹 Our DOWN → (8,3)
- If enemy goes **LEFT → (8,3)**:
  - Both heads land on **(8,3)** → **DOUBLE KO**, game ends.
  - Apples: 1–1 → **draw**.
- If enemy goes **UP → (9,4)**, we’re fine…  
- But we’re giving them a **clean head-on option**. Why let them lock in a draw when we still have space? ❌

### 🔹 Our RIGHT → (9,4)
- If enemy goes **UP → (9,4)**:
  - Both heads land on **(9,4)** → **DOUBLE KO**, 1–1 draw.
- If enemy goes **LEFT → (8,3)**, we’re chill.

### 🔹 Our UP → (8,5) ✅
- Enemy moves:
  - **UP → (9,4)** → final heads: us **(8,5)**, them **(9,4)**, no collision.
  - **LEFT → (8,3)** → final heads: us **(8,5)**, them **(8,3)**, still no collision.
- There is **no way** for them to reach **(8,5)** this turn. No head-on, no body collision. ✅

So **UP** is the only move that **cannot** result in us dying or drawing this turn, no matter what the enemy picks.

- Keeps us on the **right side lane**, perfect for building a vertical “wall” with our body in columns **7–8** later.

  - **RIGHT → (9,5)** (pressure from the side)  
- Meanwhile, enemy is still stuck in that **bottom-right corridor**. As we grow and push upward, we can eventually:
  1. Go up and over them,
  2. Wrap around from above,
  3. Use our longer body as a cage so any escape route for them runs into us 💀

**Strategy note to future me:**  
- Keep sweeping **upward on the right** for a few turns, grow safely.  
- Once we’re **ahead on apples**, THEN we start setting up forced head-on lines where any fight is in our favor.  
- Priority: **space control first, kill second**. Don’t hand them any easy draws.
